questions.given: Provide the operator that will increment a variable by 1 after that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: ++ (when used in this position) adds 1 to a number after it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a postfix operator.

questions.given: Provide the operator that will increment a variable by 1 before that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: ++ (when used in this position) adds 1 to a number before it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a prefix operator.

questions.given: Provide the operator that will decrement a variable by 1 after that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: -- (when used in this position) subtracts 1 from a number after it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a postfix operator.

questions.given: Provide the operator that will decrement a variable by 1 before that variable has been evaluated.
questions.explanation: -- (when used in this position) adds 1 to a number before it's been evaluated. This is referred to as a prefix operator.

questions.given: Provide the shortcut operator that will add 7 to x

questions.given:

addCustomer
returns either 
true
or 
false

questions.explanation: Another use for the plus operator: when used in this way, it automatically converts Boolean values into corresponding numeric ones.

questions.question: let a = b = c = 2 + 2
questions.explanation: Evaluation begins at the farthest right and works backwards, so the first operation adds 2 plus 2 to arrive at 4. That value is then assigned to the variable, c. Moving backwards one operation, the value of c (which is 4) is assigned to b. Then once again, back up and assign the value of b (4) to the variable, a.

questions.given:
const secretCode = "adi!227"
//Determine if 
secretCode
is equal to "adi!227" using regular (non-strict) equality
questions.explanation:
Regular (non-strict) equality uses double equal (
==
) and does not check to see if the values are of the same type. In general, it's safer to use strict equality triple equal (
===
), which checks both type and value.

questions.given:
const x = 57
const y = 114 / 2
//Determine if 
x
is greater than or equal to 
y

const x = 46
const y = 23 +19
//Determine if 
x
is less than or equal to 
y

const x = true
const y = 1
//Determine if 
x
is equal to 
y
(regular, not strict equality)
questions.explanation:
If you actually execute this code, you'll see that the expression returns 
true
. This is because the double equal does a type conversion such that 
true
is converted to 
1
. This is why you almost always want to use strict equality.

questions.given:
const x = true
const y = 1
//Determine if 
x
is equal to 
y
(strict equality)
questions.explanation:
If you actually execute this code, you'll see that the expression returns 
false
. This is because the triple equal does not do a type conversion. This is why you almost always want to use strict equality.

questions.given:
const x = null
const y = undefined
//Determine if 
x
is equal to 
y
(regular, non-strict equality)
questions.explanation:
If you actually execute this code, you'll see that the expression returns 
true
. This is because the double equal does some weird type-casting. I'm not sure the people who wrote this into the language originally knew how weird things would get. This is why you almost always want to use strict equality.

questions.given:
const x = null
const y = undefined
//Determine if 
x
is equal to 
y
(strict equality)
questions.explanation:
If you actually execute this code, you'll see that the expression returns 
false
. Unlike with double equal, triple equal does not do some weird type-casting. This is why you almost always want to use strict equality.

questions.given:

const y = 0
//Determine if 
x
is greater than or equal to 
y
.
questions.explanation:
If you actually execute this code, you'll see that the expression returns 
true
. This is because 
>=
does some voodoo type-casting.

questions.given:

questions.explanation:
This conditional operator evaluates the first statement: 
customerStatus === "gold"
. If this evaluates to 
true
the value immediately after the 
?
is returned. If it evaluates to 
false
, the value after the 
:
is returned.

:

if
check should see if 
status
is

let x = (true || false)
questions.question:
What will 
x
equal?
questions.explanation:
||
is a short-circuit logical operator. It looks to see if one of the values is truthy. If it finds a truthy value, it stops looking, since it already knows that the entire expression is true.

questions.question:
What will 
x
equal?
questions.explanation:
||
is a short-circuit logical operator. It looks to see if one of the values is truthy. 
1
evaluates to 
true
due to non-strict (truthy) evaluation. If it finds a truthy value, it stops looking, since it already knows that the entire expression is true.

questions.question: let x = a || b || c
questions.explanation: You can more than one or clause in an expression.

questions.given: let x = '0' === true || !true || false
questions.question:
What value will 
x
have?
questions.explanation:
The key is in the first or condition. Using strict evaluation, 
'0'
is not equal to true. Having failed the truthy test of the first part, it goes onto the second part where it encounters 
!true
. The 
!
negates the 
true
value. Then the third or condition is 
false
. Since no 
true
conditions were found, the value of 
false
is assigned to 
x

questions.given:
let x = 100
true || console.log(++x)
false || console.log(x)
questions.question: What will be printed to the console?
questions.explanation:
This might strike you as odd. What's happening? We start setting 
x = 100
. In the next line, a truthy value is found and so no further action is taken — namely incrementing 
x
and logging it. On the third line, a falsy value is encountered, causing the JavaScript interpreter to move onto the next part of the or clause. This prints the original value of 
x
to the console.

questions.given:
let x = 100
false && console.log(++x)
!true && console.log(x)
questions.question: What will be printed to the console?
questions.explanation:
&&
is a short-circuit operator. Since both statements must be true, it stops evaluating the minute it encounters a falsy value. In this case, having found falsy values for both if checks, evaluation ceases and nothing is printed to the console.

let b = 1

questions.question:

c
questions.explanation:
The 
??
is known as the nullish coalescing operator. If 
a
is neither 
null
nor 
undefined
, then the value of 
a
is returned. Otherwise, it returns the value of the second argument. In this case, 
c
would evaluate to 
1

questions.given:

case 'bronze':

discount

break
statements, execution of the code begins at the correct 
case
but then "falls through" the remaining code until it finds a 
break
or reaches the end

  case b+1:
    results = 'Buenas dias'

    break

switch

questions.given: Fill in the blank to create a recurring call to the anonymous arrow function.
Fill the blank to stop the recurring action of this code

let delay = 2000
function callAPI() {
  let rnd = Math.random()
  switch(true) {
    case rnd < 0.33:
      delay += 200
      console.log('Too fast, increasing delay to ' + delay)
      break
    case rnd >= 0.33 && rnd <.66:
      console.log('Just right, leaving delay as is at ' + delay)
      break
    default:
      delay -= 200
      console.log('Too slow, decreasing delay to ' + delay)
}
setInterval(callAPI, delay)
questions.question:
This code will adjust the length of time between 
callAPI
questions.explanation:
The value of 
delay
is set when 
setInterval
is called and is not re-evaluated on each subsequent call.

questions.given:
let delay = 2000
function callAPI() {
  let timeNow = new Date()
  console.log('Currently: ' + timeNow)
  let rnd = Math.random()
  switch(true) {
    case rnd < 0.33:
      delay += 1000
      console.log('Too fast, increasing delay to ' + delay)
      break
    case rnd >= 0.33 && rnd <.66:
      console.log('Just right, leaving delay as is at ' + delay)
      break
    default:
      delay -= 500
      console.log('Too slow, decreasing delay to ' + delay)
  }
  myTimeout = setTimeout(callAPI, delay)
}

let myTimeout = setTimeout(callAPI, delay)
questions.question:
This code will adjust the length of time between 
callAPI
questions.explanation:
Since we're using 
setTimeout
instead of 
setInterval
, the value of 
delay
will be evaluated on each iteration.

questions.given:
function cacheMachine(func) {
  let cache = new Map()
  return function(val) {
    if (cache.has(val)) {
      return cache.get(val)
    }
    let result = func(val)
    cache.set(val, result)
    return result
  }
}

function makeBox(height, width, depth) {
  return { height, width, depth }
}

let box = makeBox(510, 250, 120)

console.log(box.depth)
questions.q1: The number logged to the console will be

questions.question:
let obj = {
  Math: 'My own deviously wrong mathematical functions'
}
questions.explanation: Yes, this seems very wrong. See link for explanation.

questions.question:
let explanations = {
  [Math.pi]: 'The value of ',
  [Math.ceil]: 'A decimal value rounded up to the next integer'
}

console.log(explanations[Math.ceil])

questions.given:
let msg = "We're from the government and we're here to help."
let prevarication = msg
msg = "We're just kidding. We're here to tax you."
console.log(prevarication)
questions.question: What will log to the console?
choices: We're from the government and we're here to help
We're just kiddinig. We're here to tax you.

questions.given:
let myCat = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black'
}

let yourCat = myCat

yourCat.color = 'orange'

let myCat = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black'
}

let yourCat = myCat

console.log(myCat === yourCat)
questions.q1: The value logged to the console is

questions.given:
let myCat = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black'
}

let yourCat = {}

for (let key in myCat) {
  yourCat[key] = myCat[key]
}
yourCat.color = 'orange'
questions.question:
The color of 
myCat
is orange

questions.given:
let myCat = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black'
}

let yourCat = {}

Object.assign(yourCat, myCat)

yourCat.color = 'orange'
questions.question:
The color of 
myCat
is black

questions.given:
let amadeus = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black'
}

let namelessCat1 = {
  eats: 'fish'
}

let namelessCat2 = {
  tail: 'long'
}

let superCat = {}

Object.assign(superCat, amadeus, namelessCat1, namelessCat2)
questions.question:
amadeus
has no tail
questions.explanation: https://javascript.info/object-copy#cloning-and-merging-object-assign

questions.given:
let amadeus = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black',
  tail: 'short
}

let namelessCat1 = {
  eats: 'fish'
}

let namelessCat2 = {
  tail: 'long'
}

let superCat = {}

Object.assign(superCat, amadeus, namelessCat1, namelessCat2)
questions.question:
amadeus
has a short tail
questions.explanation: https://javascript.info/object-copy#cloning-and-merging-object-assign

questions.given:
const amadeus = {
  name: 'Amadeus',
  color: 'black',
  tail: 'short'
}

amadeus.tail = 'long'
questions.question:
This causes an error, as 
amadeus
has been declared a 
const
.

To force the garbage collector to sweep for unreferenced variables, use 
system.gc()

questions.given:
const amadeus = {
&bnsp;&bnsp;name: 'Amadeus',
&bnsp;&bnsp;color: 'black',
&bnsp;&bnsp;tail: 'short',
}

let sayHi = function() {
&bnsp;&bnsp;return `Hi, I'm ${this.name} and I'm a ${this.color} cat`
}

amadeus.sayHi = sayHi

console.log(amadeus.sayHi())
questions.question: What will running this code produce?
choices: Hi, I'm Amadeus and I'm a black cat
Hi, I'm undefined and I'm a undefined cat

Error, as 
amadeus
is declared as a 
const
Nothing — you can't assign a function to an object after it's been declared. It will be ignored.
